caption:
Photograph by Anastasia Taylor-Lind @anastasiatl | Night nurse Tamiesha Graham Baker shows �new mom Kelly Howell a feeding technique to try with baby Rooney in Long Island, New York. Before work Baker says good night to her own 10-year-old daughter, Nyiesha, who stays with an aunt until morning.
I spent five months embedded with New York City families, documenting the brutal math of caring for children in America.

Photo by Sara Hylton @sarahyltonphoto | A mother and her child at an Afghan refugee settlement, on the outskirts of Islamabad, Pakistan, pause from their daily duties. This image was made in July 2018, in the lead-up to the federal elections. Newly elected Prime Minister Imran Khan promised to grant citizenship to Afghan refugees, but over a year later, citizenship is still off the table. For more stories follow me @sarahyltonphoto #refugees #Afghanistan #Pakistan

Photo by Dina Litovsky @dina_litovsky | Shouq Faisal Madani, from Saudi Arabia, celebrates with her team at the Grand Awards Ceremony at the 2019 International Science and Engineering Fair. While historically female attendance at science fairs has been low, this year’s event was evenly split by gender, and three of the top awards went to young women.
This story about girls in science is in National Geographic’s November issue. For more images follow me @dina_litovsky.

Photo by Lynsey Addario @lynseyaddario | Deyraliz Perez Gines, 25, of Bayamon, Puerto Rico, is reprimanded by her drill instructor at Parris Island, S.C.—the only place in the country where women train to become Marines. For the next 11 weeks, they would speak only in the third person, calling themselves “this recruit” instead of “I” to absolve all individuality. Today, women make up eight percent of the United States Marine Corps. To see more of my work, follow @lynseyaddario.

Photos by Richard Barnes @richardbarnes | Can the remarkable architecture built by monstrous leaders redeem their reputations? Nero, emperor of ancient Rome, was known for killing two of his wives, allegedly killing his mother, crucifying Christians, and ordering the stoic philosopher Seneca to commit suicide. Nero was emperor when Rome burned in 64 C.E. His legacy lives on in the ambitious architectures he built, such as the Colosseum and his palace, the Domus Aurea (Golden House). It is thought that Villa Oplontis was owned by Nero and used as his second wife’s residence; its colorful frescoes have been remarkably preserved. Some say he was an avant-garde artist and visionary, his brutality simply a product of his time. Other historians define him by his obsession with popularity, and his desire for a godlike authority. Known as a public relations master, he embraced spectacle and performance on a grand scale. Follow @richardbarnes for more. #richardbarnes #nero #rome #emperors

Photo by Ian Teh @iantehphotography | I recently reviewed my photographs of China’s coal industry from 2006 to 2010 in prep for a presentation to a Nat Geo Student Expedition in Beijing. I took this photo when China was building two coal power stations a week. Today the country is set to add a further 25% to its capacity. If this extra capacity becomes operational, it would make it much more difficult for the world to limit CO2 emissions. Despite China being a global frontrunner in investing in alternative energy, this would be a major setback, according to advocates. In a BBC report last year, researchers suggested that these plants have more to do with boosting the local economies in China rather than providing any energy needs. #china #coal #climatechange #gloabalwarming #industrialisation
Photo by Tasneem Alsultan @tasneemalsultan | A teenager uses Rollerblades in front of the King Fahad National Library in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. #riyadh #saudiarabia

Photo by Diana Markosian @markosian | Sulin, 8, floats on her back in a pool in Wolfsburg, Germany. Sulin and her family arrived in Germany from Iraq as part of the migration wave in 2016. A year later, she started swimming courses as a way of allowing her to overcome the trauma she faced on the journey.

Photo by Stephen Wilkes @stephenwilkes | Photographing this glacier from a plane at 20,000 feet over Greenland, we can see it beginning to melt, the circular ring of clear blue water creating a mirror image of the sun itself. To see more photos from my travels near and far, follow me @stephenwilkes. #StephenWilkes #Glacier #Greenland #Aerial #ClimateChange

Photo by John Stanmeyer @johnstanmeyer | Today is World Tsunami Awareness Day. Haystack rock is located right off the beach in Cannon Beach, Oregon. Paleotsunami scientists say a future tsunami could hit here at any time. Cannon Beach is heavily populated with businesses and expensive homes laying in tsunami evacuation zones.

Photo by Jimmy Chin @jimmychin | The act of climbing mountains is often misunderstood. It can mean different things to different people. The reasons can be deeply personal, or about sharing an incredible experience with your climbing partners. For some it becomes a meditation in being present. Life stripped to the basics—movement through the landscape with purpose. At its most raw, it can be about survival.⁠ Conrad Anker has made a career seeking out, exploring, and climbing some of the most remote unclimbed walls in the world. Beyond climbing, he has been a mentor to new generations of climbers, and also worked to protect the wild landscapes he loves. But at the end of the day, he still loves climbing. Here in minus 20°F temps, he ascends a new 4000-foot route on Ulvetanna, aka the Wolf’s Fang, in Antarctica. Ask him why he’d spend a week on a wall in subzero temps and he might not be able to tell you...but he was surely present and enjoying this moment. For more images from mountain adventures around the world, follow @jimmychin

Photos by Babak Tafreshi @babaktafreshi | Deep in the night sky, a dark snake is hidden beyond our visual limits. Look for the S-shaped dust lane on the left, in front of the Milky Way star clouds. Swipe to zoom out and see wider angle views of this area. The tiny dark nebula known as the Snake is one of my favorite gems in the night sky. I recently photographed it next to the dazzling light of Jupiter. The Snake is like other interstellar clouds, mainly made of hydrogen, but with more dust particles and dense enough to block the light of stars behind. The Snake is little but easy to reveal in this single one-minute exposure through a telephoto lens on a small star-tracking mount. The big dark nebula in the second slide is known as the Pipe, visible to unaided eyes in a dark sky. ⁣Follow me @babaktafreshi for more of astronomy and space photography. #astrophotography #astronomy #milkyway #saveournightsky

Photo by Drew Rush @drewtrush | While we were in Yellowstone National Park this summer, we had a chance to look for wildlife every day. Catching the sunrise as you watch a group of bull elk feed is something you'll never forget—no matter how many times you may be fortunate enough to see it. Shot while on a student trip with @natgeoexpedtions. To see more wildlife images, follow along with photographer @drewtrush.

Photo by Ivan Kashinsky @ivankphoto | A man walks on the Salar de Uyuni, in Bolivia, the world’s largest salt flat. This photo was part of book project in which Karla Gachet and I traveled from the Equator to the southern tip of South America.

Photo by Gabriele Galimberti @gabrielegalimbertiphoto and Juri De Luca | Fossils of long-extinct creatures aren’t just for museums. Today they’re in homes and businesses, as wealthy collectors indulge a controversial hobby. At the Hanging Gardens of Marqueyssac in France, communications officer Stéphanie Angleys cleans the display case of a 150-million-year-old Allosaurus. Owned by French businessman Kléber Rossillon, the gardens are open to the public. Rossillon acquired the dinosaur—whose skull is among the best preserved in the world—in 2016, a few years after it was found in Wyoming. #dinosaur #fossil #extinct #dinosaurs

Photo by Brian Skerry @brianskerry | A study in the morphology of the oceanic whitetip shark. Living in the pelagic zone (open ocean), oceanic whitetips are shaped like aircrafts, with long pectoral fins that allow them to glide efficiently over long distances, expending little energy.
In 2006, I led a trip to Cat Island in The Bahamas, where we discovered a population of this species in one of the few locations left where these animals predictably can be found. Oceanic whitetip populations have been decimated due to the demand for their fins, which are prized for shark fin soup. Like the American bison, an animal that was once abundant and then hunted to the brink, only a fraction of oceanic whitetip shark populations remains today. Their numbers declined 93% between 1995 and 2010. Recovery will be difficult, because they reach sexual maturity by age seven and have small litters of pups every one to two years. To learn more about sharks and other ocean animals, follow @BrianSkerry. #oceanicwhitetip #sharks #Bahamas

Photo by Robbie Shone @shonephoto | Beneath a starry sky, a puff of pink smoke rises from Stromboli. Near the mount's base, the headlights of the last few tourist groups coming down the volcano's slope can be seen approaching the village of Stromboli, located on the coast. Every evening, tour groups hike up to the rim of the crater to watch small but energetic explosive eruptions of ash, lava, and stone blocks. Such eruptions are known as Strombolian eruptions—which occur on volcanoes throughout the world.
